entry.title: Learning With Texts (LWT) and FLTR taken down over legal dispute (who threatened to sue them?)

media:group.media:title: Learning With Texts (LWT) and FLTR taken down over legal dispute (who threatened to sue them?)
media:group.media:description:
Visit my site: https://www.mezzoguild.com My LWT setup: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=fYV3EB868Mk
One of my favorite, open source tools for language learning is/was Learning With Texts (LWT) which is basically a free alternative to LingQ (Steve Kaufmann).
Overnight, both LWT and FLTR (a similar project) were erased from Sourceforge citing a mysterious legal dispute with a link back to LingQ. Steve Kaufmann has assured us that he is not involved.
So the question remains: who threatened legal action and why?

entry.title: Keeping language lessons ethical - are we paying too little? [italki, Verbling, etc.]

media:group.media:title: Keeping language lessons ethical - are we paying too little? [italki, Verbling, etc.]
media:group.media:description: See italki here: https://www.mezzoguild.com/italki Read my huge italki review here: https://www.mezzoguild.com/italki-review I wanted to raise the question of ethical pricing for language lessons. Are we paying people too little? While it's a great thing to have a service where lessons from overseas contractors are incredibly cheap and competitive, I worry about the ethical implications of excessively low pricing. What do you think? Should there be a higher minimum cap to keep lesson pricing dignified?

entry.title: 9 actionable steps for better language learning

media:group.media:title: 9 actionable steps for better language learning
media:group.media:description:
Read more here: https://www.mezzoguild.com/better-language-learning/ In this episode, I share 9 actionable steps you can take right now that will guarantee you better language learning. --- For inexpensive language tutors, teachers and conversation partners, I use italki: https://www.mezzoguild.com/italki (sign up here and get a free lesson) --- Subscribe to this podcast on iTunes: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/language-learning-made-simple-the-mezzoguild-podcast/id1156281647?mt=2

entry.title: Staying relevant as a language learning blogger or influencer in 2019

media:group.media:title: Staying relevant as a language learning blogger or influencer in 2019
media:group.media:description: Read more here: https://www.mezzoguild.com/language-blogging/ Follow-up to my guide on blogging here: https://www.mezzoguild.com/how-to-start-a-language-blog/ I know this doesn't interest most people but from time to time I get emails asking about blogging or being an 'influencer' in the language learning niche. This is something I've been doing now for almost 8 years straight and I've learned a lot in that time. But each year I feel like a newbie myself as the Internet landscape is changing so rapidly - people consume information differently than they did just a few years ago. Here are some of my thoughts and observations.

entry.title: Ripeti Con Me! Review - Is it comparable to Glossika Italian?

media:group.media:title: Ripeti Con Me! Review - Is it comparable to Glossika Italian?
media:group.media:description:
Read my review here: https://www.mezzoguild.com/ripeti-con-me-review/ My Glossika review for comparison: https://www.mezzoguild.com/glossika-review/
I was recently sent a sample of Ripeti Con Me! by Stefano Lodola which I reviewed. It aims to be a Glossika derivative or improvement so I was keen to see just how close they are (if at all) and raise a few pertinent questions. Here are my thoughts. ---- For affordable Italian lessons, I recommend: https://www.mezzoguild.com/italki

entry.title: Yabla Review: Are language video wrappers redundant?

media:group.media:title: Yabla Review: Are language video wrappers redundant?
media:group.media:description:
Read my detailed review here: https://www.mezzoguild.com/yabla/ See Yabla here: https://www.mezzoguild.com/goto/yabla-italian FluentU: https://www.mezzoguild.com/goto/fluentu I recently put together a Yabla review as I've been exploring 'video wrapper' platforms lately. How do they remain viable with the millions of freely available videos on YouTube? Also, how do they manage to get a license to source other people's YouTube content and sell it? What makes platforms like Yabla useful? (quantity of videos or lesson depth?)
Let me know your thoughts in the comment section.

entry.title: Egyptian Arabic: Easy Stories With English Translations is now available [Paperback]

media:group.media:title: Egyptian Arabic: Easy Stories With English Translations is now available [Paperback]
media:group.media:description:
Egyptian Arabic: Easy Stories With English Translations available here: https://amzn.to/2TjQgAk Page sample images here: https://www.talkinarabic.com/egyptian-arabic-short-stories/
The first paperback edition of our new series called Egyptian Arabic: Easy Stories With English Translations is up now on Amazon. It consists of 12 mini stories in colloquial Egyptian that incrementally rise in length and difficulty.
Here’s what you’ll find in the book:
* 12 mini stories on various focus topics, full of high-frequency vocabulary and expressions pertaining to those topics. * Stories that incrementally rise in length and difficulty. * Each story has a comprehension exercise section at the end of the chapter. * Key vocabulary lists for each story (most of the main vocab used throughout the story). * Full English translations in the back of the book (away from the Arabic so you’re not tempted by it). * Large, clear font and moderate use of tashkeel (vowel markings) to improve readability for lower-level learners. * All dialogues are bolded so they’re easy to distinguish. * Lined, note-taking sections.
I really need to emphasize that this book is NOT for absolute beginners. If you’ve never studied Arabic before then I’d advise coming back to this later on.
Since it’s a first edition and a totally new venture for us, I’d love to hear your thoughts and feedback on the book.

entry.title: Memrise is moving to 'Decks' [How to save your language courses to Anki]

media:group.media:title: Memrise is moving to 'Decks' [How to save your language courses to Anki]
media:group.media:description:
Visit my blog and subscribe at: https://www.mezzoguild.com/
Memrise just announced that they're rebranding to a free community site called Decks.
It's unclear if this will change any of the current functionality of Memrise courses (they seem to insist it won't). Either way, it's actually really easy to download your existing courses to your computer as Anki decks.
Go to nodejs.org and download your OS' version of npm (Node Package Manager). If you're using Linux or BSD, you can install npm through your system's ports or packages.
Run: npm install memanki-cli -g
Then run: memanki --id ####### (course ID number taken from url in your browser)
You can also run: memanki --merge --id ####### (this will merge all course decks into one big deck.

entry.title: How to use Audacity track labels for language learning [+ convert them to subtitles]

media:group.media:title: How to use Audacity track labels for language learning [+ convert them to subtitles]
media:group.media:description:
Visit my blog for more: https://www.mezzoguild.com Content used from: https://www.talkinarabic.com
**Correction: .SRT subtitles need a comma after the seconds, not a full stop. e.g. 00:00:00,000 - not: 00:00:00.000. Won't work otherwise.**
I've talked about Audacity briefly before.
I use it religiously in my own language learning and it's got a lot of uses. One of which is track labeling and converting those track labels to subtitles.
Like this style of video? Let me know in the comment section and I'll do more just like it.

entry.title: Korean Stories For Language Learners (Review) [Traditional Folktales]

media:group.media:title: Korean Stories For Language Learners (Review) [Traditional Folktales]
media:group.media:description:
More info about the book here: https://www.mezzoguild.com/goto/korean-stories Visit my blog here: https://www.mezzoguild.com/
I recently received a copy of Korean Stories For Language Learners by Julie Damron and EunSun You (Tuttle Publishing).
The book covers 42 total short stories in Korean with English translations, comprehension exercises, vocab lists and full audio listening material.
Since the 'short story' niche of learning material seems to be trending at the moment, I thought I'd take time to check this one out. Rather than covering typical dialogue material, it focuses on traditional Korean folktales. The audio is a pleasure to listen to.
A few minor things to point out: absolute beginner material is inappropriate for this book (there's not much of it so it's not a major issue) and some exercises are borderline bizarre (but still funny).
Something a dedicated Korean student who loves Korean history and culture would definitely enjoy reading.

entry.title: Learning *about* a language does not mean you've *learned* a language [Re: MT method devotees]

media:group.media:title: Learning *about* a language does not mean you've *learned* a language [Re: MT method devotees]
media:group.media:description:
This is in reference to: https://www.mezzoguild.com/michel-thomas-review/
I get that we all have our favorite methods, products, courses, etc. for learning a foreign language. I have mine.
Over the last year in particular, I've received a lot of pushback on my comments re: Michel Thomas. People seem religiously devoted to this method. It may just be because I'm wrong and the method's amazing but I think there's another reason:
Learning a lot *about* a language can leave you feeling as if you've *learned* the language.
There's a big difference.
What are your thoughts?

entry.title: Globalism has ruined adventure and is making the world boring

media:group.media:title: Globalism has ruined adventure and is making the world boring
media:group.media:description: Visit my blog on language learning here: https://www.mezzoguild.com Just been reflecting lately on the fact that the world is, for the first time ever, completely and utterly discovered. We have every last inch of the planet (except for the ocean floor) mapped out and accessible with a swipe of the finger. What does this mean for the future? What does it mean for language learning and foreign cultures?
